sentences.sentence: And on the next day the Woodcutter( 伐木工 ) took the golden fabric( 布料 ) that he had found the Star-Child with, and placed it in a great chest( 大箱子 ).
There had also been a necklace( 项链 ) of amber( 琥珀 ) around the child’s neck, and his wife took this and put it in the chest( 大箱子 ) as well.
And so the Star-Child was brought up( 被抚养 ) with the children of the Woodcutter( 伐木工 ).
He sat at the same table with them, and played with them.
And every year he became more beautiful, so that all those who lived in the village were filled with( 充满 ) wonder.
Most of them had dark skin and dark hair, but his skin was as white as pearls( 珍珠 ), and his hair was curled( 蜷曲的 ) and golden.
His lips( 嘴唇 ), also, were red like the petals( 花瓣 ) of a rose, and his eyes were deep blue like sapphires( 蓝宝石 ).
Everything about him was perfect and beautiful.
Yet his beauty made him cruel( 残忍的 ), and proud, and selfish( 自私的 ).
He hated the children of the Woodcutter( 伐木工 ), and the other children of the village.
He said they were all the children of poor people, but he was noble( 高贵的 ), because he had come from a star.
He acted like their master( 主人 ), and called them his servants( 仆人 ).
He had no pity for the poor, or for those who were blind or injured( 受伤的 ) or sick.
Instead, he threw stones at them, and chased( 驱逐 ) them out of the village, telling them to go and beg( 乞讨 ) elsewhere.
He loved only himself, and in the summer he would lie down and look into a lake, staring( 凝视 ) with wonder at his own face and laughing with joy( 喜悦 ) at how beautiful he was.
Often the Woodcutter( 伐木工 ) and his wife scolded( 训斥 ) him, and said: “We did not treat you like you treat those less fortunate( 幸运的 ) than you, when we took care of you as a baby.
Why are you so cruel( 残忍的 ) to all those who need pity?”
But the Star-Child always ignored( 不理会 ) their words, and said rude( 无礼的 ) things to them, and then went back to his friends.
Wherever the Star-Child led them, they followed, and whatever the Star-Child told them to do, they did.
When he used a stick to poke( 戳 ) out the eyes of a mole( 鼹鼠 ), they laughed.
And when he threw stones at the beggars( 乞丐 ) they laughed too.
He ruled them like a master( 主人 ), and they became as cold-hearted as he was.
One day a poor beggar-woman( 女乞丐 ) passed through the village.
Her clothes were torn( 破烂的 ) and dirty, and her feet were bleeding from the rough( 崎岖的 ) road on which she had traveled.
She felt very tired, and sat down under a tree to rest.
But when the Star-Child saw her, he said to his friends,
“Look! There is a disgusting( 令人厌恶的 ) beggar-woman( 女乞丐 ) under that beautiful, green tree.
Come, let us chase( 驱逐 ) her away, for she is ugly and unfortunate( 穷困潦倒的 ).”
And then he started to throw stones at the woman and laugh at her.
She looked at him with terror( 恐惧 ) in her eyes, but she did not look away.
Then the Woodcutter( 伐木工 ), who was working nearby, saw what the Star-Child was doing.
He ran up to him and said. “You are a cruel( 残忍的 ) boy, with a cold heart.
What has this poor woman done to you to make you treat her this way?”
The Star-Child grew red with anger, and stamped his foot( 跺脚 ) upon the ground, and said, “Who are you to question what I do?
I am no son of yours, and I do not need to listen to you.”
“That is true,” answered the Woodcutter( 伐木工 ).
“Yet I showed pity on you, when I found you in the forest.”
When the woman heard these words she gave a loud cry, and passed out( 昏倒 ).
The Woodcutter( 伐木工 ) carried her to his own house, and his wife cared for her.
When she woke up( 醒来 ), they gave her food and drink.
But she would neither eat nor drink, and said to the Woodcutter( 伐木工 ),
“Did you say that the child was found in the forest? And was it not ten years ago that you found him?”
And the Woodcutter( 伐木工 ) answered, “Yes, it was in the forest that I found him, and it was ten years ago.”
“And what things did you find with him?” she cried.
“Was he wearing an amber( 琥珀 ) necklace( 项链 )? Was he inside a piece of golden fabric( 布料 ), covered with stars?”
“He was,” answered the Woodcutter( 伐木工 ). “It is exactly as you say.”
And he took the golden fabric( 布料 ) and the amber( 琥珀 ) necklace( 项链 ) from the chest( 大箱子 ) where he had kept them, and showed them to her.
When she saw them she cried for joy( 喜悦 ), and said, “He is my little son whom I lost in the forest.
I beg( 恳求 ) you to bring him quickly to me, for I have wandered( 流浪 ) over the whole world searching for him.”
